column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Paderno d'Adda
#Text=Paderno d'Adda is a small village in the Lecco province of
#Text=Lombardy , northern Italy , located on the southern edge of the Italian Prealps , south of the city of Lecco , and near the northeastern edge of Greater Milan .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Paderno d'Adda is famous for its old iron bridge ( the San Michele Bridge ) and it is a good gateway to the Adda river .
#Text=It has a connection with Leonardo Da Vinci , who lived and worked for some time in the nearby town of Vaprio d'Adda .
#Text=An open air museum ( Ecomuseo Adda di Leonardo ) celebrates the Italian genius and his works along the Adda river .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Paderno d'Adda is not far from Milan , making it a good choice for a day trip .
#Text=Be careful to not confuse Paderno d'Adda with Paderno Dugnano , these are two different towns .
#Text=By train
#Text=The Paderno d'Adda/Robbiate train station is 1km/0.6mi from the bridge and the river .
#Text=Regular trains run from Milano Porta Garibaldi station ( direction Bergamo via Carnate ) .
#Text=By car
#Text=Take the A51 ( tangenziale est ) motorway northward up to Agrate , then continue toward Lecco .
#Text=The road is an high speed freeway up to Carnate , then turns into a regular road .
#Text=When you reach Cernusco Lombardone turn to the right and you will reach the San Michele Bridge in Paderno d'Adda .
#Text=Get around
#Text=The village is quite small and the river bank is only accessible by foot or by bike .
#Text=There are no signs in the village , so take a map with you .
#Text=See
#Text=The San Michele Bridge .
#Text=The San Michele Bridge ( locally known simply as the Paderno Bridge ) is more than 100 years old , since it was built in 1889 to cross the Adda river .
#Text=The iron bridge is 85mt high and 266mt long , and Its structure resembles closely the Eiffel Tower .
#Text=It has a double-deck structure , with the upper deck reserved to vehicular traffic and the lower deck used by the Milano-Bergamo train line .
#Text=The bridge is still opened to vehicles , with a traffic light regulating the traffic ( only one way by turns ) .
#Text=Be aware that , due to the advanced age of the structure , heavier vehicles are forbidden to cross the bridge .
#Text=The train crosses the bridge between Paderno d'Adda and Calusco stations .
#Text=While Paderno station is near the bridge , Calusco is quite far away .
#Text=Do
#Text=From San Michele Bridge , you can reach the Adda river bank .
#Text=At the left of the bridge you will see a little chapel , here departs the road which leads to the river bank .
#Text=Pay attention to the difference in height : the river lies 85mt below the bridge level and there is a steep road to climb when you return .
#Text=The river bank is reserved to pedestrian and cyclists .
#Text=Expect a lot of people during sunny week-ends , since this is favourite place for locals to go walking , biking and jogging .
#Text=Pay attention to little children , especially if you ride a bike .
#Text=The river bank is a great spot for photographers and can also be a quiet and peaceful place ( when it 's not packed with people ) .
#Text=Northward
#Text=Turn left and walk northward ( leave the river at your right ) .
#Text=Imbersago and Leonardo 's ferry boat . you can reach Imbersago and its ferry boat .
#Text=It 's a 40 minutes long walk , on a flat path .
#Text=During the trip you can enjoy the quiet river bank and spot many birds and little animals .
#Text=In Imbersago you can see Leonardo 's ferry boat .
#Text=The ferry boat has no engine , it crosses the river using solely the river flow force .
#Text=Leonardo wrote down some notes about this kind of boat , although it 's not certain if he designed it or he just observed some of these boats already active during the time he spent here .
#Text=Leonardo 's notes and drawings about the ferry are contained in the Windsor Codex and copies are on display at the ferry 's embarcadero .
#Text=In the past up to five of these boats crossed the river at various locations .
#Text=Nowadays this is the only ferry left using the moving principle drawn by Leonardo .
#Text=It operates daily and it can carry persons , bikes and even one or two cars , but there is not much to see on the other bank .
#Text=The service may be suspended if the water level is too low .
#Text=Southward
#Text=Turn right and walk southward ( leave the river at your left ) you can pass under the San Michele Bridge and continue along the river bank .
#Text=Naviglio di Paderno .
#Text=Naviglio di Paderno is an artificial channel built to overcome the rapids on this part of the river and make the navigation between Milan ( via the Martesana channel ) and Como lake possible .
#Text=The first project was made by Leonardo on behalf of Francis I of France , but it was not built until 1777 .
#Text=Unfortunately the channel is not used anymore , due to the lack of interest in river navigation .
#Text=It is now active as a dam for nearby hydroelectric plants .
#Text=Forra d'Adda rapids .
#Text=Continuing southward you will reach the Forra d'Adda rapids ( 1km/0.6mi from the bridge ) , this is where the river flows most rapidly .
#Text=A detail of three rock emerging from the river is believed to be painted on the background of Leonardo 's La vergine delle rocce .
#Text=Santuario della Madonna della Rocchetta .
#Text=The Santuario della Madonna della Rocchetta ( 2.8km/1.7mi from the bridge ) offers a great view on the river .
#Text=Bertini and Carlo Esterle power plants .

#Text=Continuing along the bank it 's possible to reach the Bertini and Carlo Esterle ( 5km/3mi from the bridge ) power plants , the second one is a real monument : it 's build to look like an eclectic-style palace rather than an ordinary power plant .
#Text=The path on the river bank then continues for many kilometers , eventually joining the Martesana channel which goes straight to the center of Milan .
#Text=Pay attention to not push yourself too far , remember that you have to go back and there are no easy transportation systems to rely upon .
#Text=Be also aware that the path climbs down on this direction , always remember that you have to go back .
